question: Question_B_05_(b)
statement:
Consider the differential equation system

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y}' = A\mathbf{y} ~\end{align*} where \emph{A} has an eigenvalue
$\lambda_1 = 1 + 2i$ with corresponding eigenvector

\begin{align*}\mathbf{k}_{1}=\left[ \begin{array}{c}
2+3i\\
1
\end{array} \right]\end{align*}

Recall that for real matrices, eigenvalues and eigenvectors come in
complex conjugate pairs.

Find the real form (no imaginary terms) of the solution that satisfies
initial conditions
$\mathbf{y}(0)=\left[ \begin{array}{c} 1\\ 0 \end{array} \right]$
sols:
Continuing from the hint, to choose real-valued solutions, we choose
$C_2 = \bar{C_1}$, so that the general solution becomes:

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y} = C_1 \mathbf{y_1} + C_2 \mathbf{y_2} = C_1 \mathbf{y_1} + \overline{C_1 \mathbf{y_1}} = 2 \mathrm{Re}\left[ C_1 \mathbf{y_1} \right]\end{align*}

Recall that

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y_1} = \mathbf{k_1} \exp{\lambda_1 t} = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2+3i \\ 1 \end{array} \right] \exp{(1+2i)t}\end{align*}

Since

\begin{align*}\mathrm{Re} \left[ \mathbf{y_1} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] e^t \cos{2t} + \left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] e^t \sin{2t}\end{align*}

\begin{align*}\mathrm{Im} \left[ \mathbf{y_1} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] e^t \cos{2t} + \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] e^t \sin{2t}\end{align*}

The general form of real-valued solutions is:

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{y} &= D_1 \mathrm{Re} \left[ \mathbf{y_1} \right] + D_2 \mathrm{Im} \left[ \mathbf{y_1} \right] \\
&= D_1 \left( \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] e^t \cos{2t} + \left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] e^t \sin{2t} \right)\\
&+ D_2 \left( \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] e^t \cos{2t} + \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] e^t \sin{2t} \right)\end{align*}

where $D_1$ and $D_2$ are real constants.

Their relationship with the previous constants are
$D_1 = 2 \mathrm{Re} \left[ C_1 \right]$ and
$D_2 = -2 \mathrm{Im} \left[ C_1 \right] = e^t$

Now if we impose the initial condition
$\mathbf{y}(0) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right]$, we
get

\begin{align*}D_1 \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] + D_2 \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right]
=  \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right]\end{align*}

Thus, $D_1 = 0 ~$ and $D_2 = \frac{1}{3}$, and the solution of the
initial value problem is

\begin{align*}\frac{1}{3} \left( \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] e^t \cos{2t} + \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] e^t \sin{2t} \right)
= \frac{e^t}{3} \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \cos{2t} + 2 \sin{2t} \\ \sin{2t} \end{array} \right]\end{align*}

Alternatively, one can solve directly from

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y} = 2 \mathrm{Re}\left[ C_1 \mathbf{y_1} \right]\end{align*}

And impose the initial condition
$\mathbf{y}_0 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right]$
direcly to find that $C_1 = -\frac{i}{6}$.

Then compute the real part to get the same result as above. The amount
of algebra involved will be slightly less.
hints:
The two particular solutions from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2010/Question_B5_(a)}{part
(a)} (each was formed using a pair of eigenvalue and eigenvector of
\emph{A}), i.e. $\mathbf{y}_1, \mathbf{y}_2$ come in complex conjugate
pairs too. That means they satisfy $\mathbf{y}_2 = \bar{\mathbf{y}_1}$.

Now, the general complex-valued solution from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2010/Question_B5_(a)}{part
(a)} is a linear combination of these with arbitrary complex constants
$C_1, C_2 ~$. What form of such constants, then, $C_1, C_2 ~$ must we
choose so that when placed in front of $\mathbf{y}_1$ and
$\mathbf{y}_2$, we can obtain a real-valued solution?

You might need to concentrate on the follow fact for complex numbers:

\begin{align*}z + \bar{z} = 2 \mathrm{Re}[z]\end{align*}

is always a real number for any complex number \emph{z}.

Think about how $C_1,C_2 ~$ should be related to each other.
